Many [[Arab people|Arabs]] in the Middle East and North Africa see Bouazizi as a hero and inspiration.<ref name="ArabNews">{{cite web|url=http://arabnews.com/lifestyle/offbeat/article247965.ece|last=Jansen|first=Michael|title=Ben Ammar to produce film on Tunisian hero Bouazizi|publisher=[[Al-Sharq al-Awsat]]|work=[[Arab News]]|date=2011-02-01|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0118/1224287759638.html|last=Jansen|first=Michael|title=Egyptian injured in self-immolation protest|work=The Irish Times |work=The Irish Times |date=2011-01-18|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref> He is credited with galvanising the frustrations of the region's youth against their governments into [[Arab Spring|mass demonstrations, revolts, and revolutions]].<ref name="CNN">{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-22/world/tunisia.bouazizi.arab.unrest_1_fruit-vendor-sidi-bouzid-abedine-ben-ali?_s=PM:WORLD|last=Watson|first=Ivan|title=The Tunisian fruit seller who kickstarted Arab uprising|publisher=Cable News Network|publisher=CNN|date=2011-03-22|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref> Bouazizi is considered a martyr by the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]] (PDP) of Tunisia.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> Tunisian film director, [[Mohamed Zran]], plans on making a feature film about Bouazizi, describing him as "a symbol for eternity."<ref name="CNN"/> [[Tarak Ben Ammar]], also a Tunisian film director, intends to make a film on Bouazizi as well, stating he is "a hero for us as Tunisians and the Arab world as a whole."<ref name="ArabNews"/> Since suicide is forbidden in Islam, Bouazizi's self-immolation created controversy among scholarly Muslim circles. Bouazizi's actions triggered [[Copycat suicide|the Werther effect]], causing a number of self-immolations in protests emulating Bouazizi's in several other countries in the [[Greater Middle East]] and Europe. In [[Algeria]] in particular, protests against rising food prices and spreading unemployment<ref name="Chinadaily">{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2011-01-25/content_1642189.html |title=Algeria reports 2nd death of self-immolation |author=Xinhua |date=2011-01-25 |work=China Daily |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> have resulted in [[2011 Algerian self-immolations|many self-immolations]]. The first reported case following Bouazizi's death was that of Mohsen Bouterfif, a 37-year-old father of two, who set himself on fire when the mayor of [[Boukhadra]] in Algeria refused to meet with him and others regarding employment and housing requests on January 13, 2011. According to a report in ''[[El-Watan]]'', the mayor challenged him, saying if he had courage he would immolate himself by fire as Bouazizi had done.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1210-le-maire-a-mohcin-bouterfif-l-si-tu-as-du-courage-fais-comme-bouazizi-immole-toi-par-le-feu-r.html |title=Le maire Ã  Mohcin Bouterfif : " Si tu as du courage, fais comme Bouazizi, immole-toi par le feu " |publisher=DNA-Algerie |language=French |author=Benslimane, Mehdi & Slim Badaoui |date=2011-01-24 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> He died on January 24. Maamir Lotfi, a 36-year-old unemployed father of six, also denied a meeting with the governor, burned himself in front of the [[El Oued]] town hall on January 17, dying on February 12.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110212105526/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-manifestationquatrieme-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-a-la-veille-de-la-marche-du-12-fevrier.html |title=QuatriÃ¨me dÃ©cÃ¨s par immolation en AlgÃ©rie, Ã  la veille de la marche du 12 fÃ©vrier |language=French |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-02-22}}</ref> Abdelhafid Boudechicha, a 29-year-old day laborer who lived with his parents and five siblings, burned himself in [[Medjana]] on January 28 over employment and housing issues.
